title: Ticket #2616: Create a command-line tool to communicate with DAGMan
description:
Right now the user can basically communicate with a running DAGMan only via the condor_rm and condor_hold commands, and we (Pete and I) think that this is too coarse-grained. (A couple of examples -- on condor_rm, should a final node be run or not, and should a rescue DAG be created, or should things just be killed off as quickly as possible; and, on a condor_hold, should the DAGMan job actually be killed, or should it be told to just stop submitting node jobs.)

There are plenty of other possibilities, too, such as querying the state of the DAG.

We're thinking that this should be a new command-line tool, like condor_dag_tool or something. Since DAGMan is daemoncore, it has a command socket; it could put the address for that into its classad, and then the DAG tool could get the address from the schedd, and talk to DAGMan directly after that.
remarks:
2011-Nov-07 16:45:23 by wenger:
This tool should also be able to change configuration settings for DAGMan (e.g., maxjobs). It might also eventually become a way of dynamically changing the actual DAG, although we also had other proposals for how to deal with that.

2011-Nov-07 19:37:39 by nwp:
#2438 is duplicate of this ticket. I will delete that and point to this.

2012-Apr-06 10:52:46 by pfc:
Just to import another use-case from #2663, which was closed as a dup with this ticket, this tool should replace/support controlling the <dagname>.halt files to gracefully halt a running DAG.

2012-May-02 15:01:14 by nwp:
This is something I would like to do for 7.9. Instead of deriving from #2213, I will repoint to #2810

2014-Aug-11 13:23:59 by wenger:
What are some things such a tool should be able to do?:
  • Halt/un-halt DAG.
  • Add nodes.
  • "Manually" re-try specified nodes.
  • Possibly various flavors of removing the DAG (such as having DAGMan stay in the queue until all child jobs have exited the queue).
  • Maybe change node priorities on the fly.
  • Peacefully pause the DAG (see #3756).
  • Dump a rescue DAG but continue to run.
  • Get and report stats on the state of the DAG.
  • Probably a bunch of other things...

(I wonder if this would be something that it would make sense for Zach to work on, because he knows daemoncore better than I do.)

2014-Aug-11 13:25:05 by wenger:
What should such a tool be named? condor_dag_cmd?

2014-Aug-11 15:10:35 by wenger:
More stuff for this tool to do:
  • Change DAGMan settings, such as maxjobs, maxidle, DAGMAN_USER_LOG_SCAN_INTERVAL, DAGMAN_MAX_SUBMITS_PER_INTERVAL, etc.

2014-Aug-11 15:14:26 by wenger:
The command-line format maybe could be something like this: 

  condor_dag_cmd [-name scheddname] <cluster id> <command> <command> ...

Maybe have the option to specify 

  -addr <a.b.c.d:port>

instead of "[-name scheddname] <cluster id>" to be able to bypass the schedd.

2014-Aug-12 09:27:01 by wenger:
There are a number of tickets that could benefit from this functionality:
  • #2831: Be able to "manually" retry nodes during a DAG run
  • #3756: provide command to peacefully pause a DAG
  • #1756: Be able to dynamically add nodes to a running DAG
  • #1311: Be able to configure DAGMan's actions when condor_rm'ed
  • #4356: Have some way to do a reconfig on a running DAGMan

2015-Jun-04 12:47:45 by wenger:
Hmm -- I just thought of a simpler way to do this that would be easier and quicker to implement: each time through the submission loop, DAGMan looks for a specific file (foo.dag.cmd or something), and, if the file exists, DAGMan executes whatever commands are in the file, and then removes the file.

One other thing I was thinking about is this: if we allow commands (whether via the file or other means) that do things like adding nodes, we need to have some way of recording them for rescue and recovery modes -- otherwise, the new nodes won't get created in those modes.

One possibility I thought of is this: we create a rescue DAG file when DAGMan first starts up, and we record the "dynamic" commands in that file as we go. Then, if we finish successfully, we remove the rescue DAG file. I think that might work for both rescue and recovery modes, although I need to do a little more thinking to make sure that it would work for recovery mode. Also note that we might not need to record all commands -- for example, if a command is to do a reconfig, any changes to the config file(s) would take effect automatically in recovery or rescue mode anyhow.

2016-Oct-30 18:25:07 by wenger:
Okay, probably the most obvious use for this would be changing parameters like maxjobs on the fly...
